title-group.article-title: Commentary on ‘Effect of dexmedetomidine for epidural supplementation on postpartum sleep disturbance after cesarean delivery: a double-blind, randomized clinical trial”

body.p: Disruption and redistribution of sleep during the postpartum period are common. Whether assessed subjectively or objectively, postpartum women are more likely to experience interrupted, fragmented, and poor-quality sleep[1]. Studies have shown that poor postpartum sleep quality not only increases postpartum weight retention, but also multiplies the risk of postpartum depression; in addition, it is strongly associated with safety risks such as impaired daytime functioning and near-miss motor vehicle accidents[2-4]. This commentary was prepared in accordance with the Transparency In The reporting of Artificial INtelligence guideline[5], with AI assistance limited to language translation of non-sensitive text.

Li et al[6] conducted a single-center, randomized, double-blind study to analyze the effect of intraoperative low-dose dexmedetomidine epidural supplementation on postpartum sleep quality and the postpartum sleep disorder incidences in patients undergoing caesarean delivery. They found that intraoperative and postoperative continuous epidural infusion of low-dose dexmedetomidine significantly improved postpartum sleep quality and reduced the incidence of postpartum sleep disturbances. These findings are clinically important for the treatment of postpartum sleep disorders; however, further research is required.

First, this study effectively controlled for potential bias through a randomized, prospective, double-blind design, and the methodological rigor was commendable. However, the sample size of only 60 patients in each group was relatively small, which may weaken the validity of the statistical results. Subsequent studies should expand the sample size to enhance the reliability and generalizability of the findings.

Second, although this study controlled for confounders through strict exclusion criteria, it is recommended to exclude pregnant women with a recent history of alcohol dependence (although such women were limited). Given that alcohol independently affects the sleep cycle, it may confound core variables, such as postoperative pain and sleep quality[7,8]. This adjustment would further improve the scientific validity of the study and the credibility of the conclusions, avoiding potential interference with assessing postoperative pain and sleep quality.

Finally, several potential confounders were not adequately controlled. First, mother-infant interaction patterns, such as rooming-in and breastfeeding practices, significantly increase the frequency of nocturnal infant care, with feeding demands and crying directly contributing to fragmented maternal sleep. Second, due to circadian rhythms, prolactin secretion peaks at night, causing breast swelling and pain, which not only leads to physiological discomfort but also induce anxiety. Overactivation of the sympathetic nervous system significantly prolongs sleep latency. Notably, bidirectional is associated with maternal sleep quality and mental health: postpartum anxiety and depressive states exacerbate sleep disorders through neuroendocrine mechanisms, while difficulties in maintaining sleep (especially reduced slow-wave sleep) impair mood regulation, creating a vicious sleep-mood cycle. Epidemiological studies have confirmed that perinatal insomnia increases postpartum depression risk by 3.46-fold, leading to increase the incidence of sleep disorders by depression symptoms[3,9]. Considering these confounders could further robust the research findings.

In conclusion, this study provides an important clinical rationale for optimising postoperative analgesic strategies and improving maternal sleep quality after caesarean section. Dexmedetomidine, a highly selective α2-adrenoceptor agonist administered epidurally, not only significantly lowers early postoperative sleep disturbances incidence but also reduces ropivacaine consumption and the need for patient-controlled analgesia. These finding support the central role of multimodal analgesic strategies in perioperative management and provide novel insights for obstetric procedures that requiring balancing analgesic efficacy with maternal and infant safety. Epidural drug combinations have demonstrated advantages in various surgical procedures, including orthopedic arthroplasty and major thoracic and abdominal surgeries. This study further highlights the potential of low-dose dexmedetomidine in obstetric anesthesia by enhancing the analgesic efficacy of local anesthetics while providing sedative and anxiolytic effects. Therefore, it may represent key tool to improve maternal postoperative recovery.

Despite limitations in sample size and subjective assessment methods, this study provides a foundation for future research. We recommend controlling for potential confounders as much as possible in future randomized controlled trial studies; researchers and clinicians also need to pay attention to the profound effects of the postnatal environment on sleep structure, including infant care needs, physiological adaptations (e.g. breastfeeding) and maternal mental health; and understand the bidirectional relationship between sleep and depression. Additionally, it is recommended incorporating objective sleep monitoring, such as somatokinetic recorders, in follow-up to validate the results and expanding the sample to include high-risk populations, such as patients with pre-pregnancy sleep disorders. Long-term monitoring of maternal and infant safety, including infant neurodevelopment, and assessing the risk of drug transfer via breast milk would further improve clinical decision-making. Our suggestions are merely aimed at further refining this outstanding study. We look forward to additional ground-breaking contributions from the authors in future studies.
